content.text: Plans or approaches investors use to select, manage, and grow their investments based on goals, risk tolerance, and market outlook.
Purpose: To guide decision-making, manage risk, and maximize returns over time.
Investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of market price.
Reduces the impact of market volatility and avoids trying to time the market.

content.title: Example
items: Investing $500 every month into a stock or ETF. You buy more shares when prices are low and fewer shares when prices are high.

content.text: Benefit: Smooths out investment risk over time, making it easier for long-term growth.
Risk: May underperform if markets consistently rise and lump-sum investing would have been better.

items: Focuses on stocks that appear undervalued based on fundamentals (e.g., low P/E ratio, strong assets).
Goal: Buy low, sell high over the long term.
Suitable for investors seeking stability and long-term growth.
Focuses on companies expected to grow earnings faster than the market average.
Often involves higher valuation ratios, but with potential for high returns.
Suitable for investors willing to accept higher risk for higher growth.

content.text: Investing based on trends and price momentum, buying assets that are rising and selling those that are falling.
Seeks to capitalize on short- to medium-term market movements.

content.title: Example
items: Buying a stock after a strong quarterly earnings report, expecting the uptrend to continue.

content.text: Benefit: Can generate quick returns if trends continue.
Risk: Markets can reverse unexpectedly, leading to losses.
Focuses on generating steady cash flow from investments, such as dividends from stocks or interest from bonds.
Provides passive income and can be more stable in volatile markets.
Benefit: Provides regular income and potential for long-term growth.
Risk: Income may fluctuate, and capital gains may be limited compared to growth strategies.

items: Choose an investment strategy that aligns with your goals, risk tolerance, and time horizon.
Dollar-cost averaging helps reduce timing risk and smooths out investments over time.
Value investing focuses on stability and buying undervalued stocks, while growth investing targets high potential growth.
Momentum trading seeks short-term gains but is riskier.
Income investing provides steady cash flow and can stabilize portfolios in volatile markets.
